q: 1. My bike, _____ I bought last year, is already broken.
expl: which – Non-defining relative clauses for things take “which,” not “that.”

q: 2. She didn’t tell me _____ she had finished the report.
expl: that – Reporting verbs are usually followed by an object noun clause introduced by “that.”

q: 3. Call me as soon as you _____ home.
expl: get – Time clauses with “as soon as” use the present simple for future meaning.

q: 4. If I _____ the answer, I would tell you.
expl: knew – Second-conditional sentences use the past simple in the if-clause to show an unreal present situation.

q: 5. My sister, _____ lives in London, is coming to visit.
expl: who – A non-defining relative clause referring to a person requires “who.”

q: 6. _____ he was tired, he kept working.
expl: Although – Introduces a concessive adverbial clause expressing contrast.

q: 7. _____ she will pass the exam remains uncertain.
expl: Whether – Subject noun clauses that present alternatives are introduced by “whether.”

q: 8. He whispered so that he _____ wake the baby.
expl: wouldn't – Purpose clauses with “so that” often use “would(n’t)” to show intended (non-)results.

q: 9. The professor _____ I spoke was very helpful.
expl: to whom – Formal style keeps the preposition before the relative pronoun when referring to people.

q: 10. The book _____ lies on the table is mine.
expl: which – A defining relative clause for a thing requires “which”; other choices are ungrammatical here.

q: 11. If he had taken the medicine, he _____ better now.
expl: would feel – A mixed (third + second) conditional uses past perfect in the if-clause and “would” + base verb for a present result.

q: 12. He spoke so quietly that nobody _____ him.
expl: heard – The result clause refers to a past event, so the simple past is required.

q: 13. It is important that she _____ on time.
expl: arrive – The mandative subjunctive after adjectives like “important” takes the base form.

q: 14. If it _____ tomorrow, we'll stay indoors.
expl: rains – First-conditional sentences use the present simple in the if-clause to refer to a future possibility.

q: 15. Students _____ late will not be allowed in.
expl: arriving – A reduced defining relative clause uses the present participle for an ongoing action.

q: 16. Mr. Brown, _____ car was stolen, reported it to the police.
expl: whose – The relative pronoun “whose” shows possession in both defining and non-defining clauses.

q: 17. I suggest that he _____ more exercise.
expl: take – After verbs of suggestion, the subjunctive base form is used (no –s).

q: 18. If water _____ frozen, it expands.
expl: is – Zero-conditional sentences for general truths use the present simple in both clauses.

q: 19. He failed the test because he _____.
expl: hadn't studied – The past perfect shows the cause happened before the past result.

q: 20. January is the month _____ many people make resolutions.
expl: when – For a noun of time, the appropriate relative adverb is “when,” equivalent to “in which.”
